inlineContent.text: class to generate an ephemeral token that
identifies a device, your server uses HTTP
commands to send requests to the
query and update endpoints. The HTTP header field in each request must contain the
authentication key you receive from Apple in a JSON web token (JWT). To create this
token, you can use the same steps you use to create a provider authentication token
for Apple Push Notification service (APNs); for details, see

content.text: Create the payload for a query request

inlineContent.text: To query the bits, you create a JSON payload that contains the fields listed in the
Base 64–encoded representation of encrypted device information
Unique transaction identifier from the associated server
UTC timestamp from the associated server, in milliseconds since the Unix epoch
Here’s an example of a payload included in a query request:
When your query request succeeds, you receive a response that contains the fields
The value of the first bit
The value of the second bit
The date of the last modification, in YYYY-MM format

content.text: Create the payload for an update request

inlineContent.text: To update the bits, you create a JSON payload that contains the fields listed in
Base 64–encoded representation of encrypted device information
Unique transaction identifier from the associated server
UTC timestamp from the associated server, in milliseconds since the Unix epoch
Value to set for the first bit
Value to set for the second bit
Here’s an example of a payload included in an update request:
If the update was successful, you receive the HTTP response code
list of the response codes you can receive, see Understand the HTTP response codes.

content.text: Create the payload for a device validation request

inlineContent.text: To validate a device, you create a JSON payload that contains the fields listed in
Base 64–encoded representation of encrypted device information
Unique transaction identifier from the associated server
UTC timestamp from the associated server, in milliseconds since the Unix epoch
Here’s an example of a payload included in a device-validation request:
If the request was successful, you receive the HTTP response code
list of response codes you can receive, see Understand the HTTP response codes.
Each request you send to the query and update endpoints must include an authorization
header that contains your authentication key. The authentication key must use the
ES256 algorithm and be in the Base 64 URL–encoded JSON web token format. If your
token doesn’t use this format, you receive a
command you create to send a request, you specify the authorization
header and include your authentication key using
Use the base URL shown in the example
for testing during development. When you’re ready to transition to a production environment,
you must use the production base URL

When you use the query and update endpoints to communicate with the server, you may
receive one of the response codes listed in the table below.
The device token is missing or badly formatted
The bits are missing or badly formatted
The timestamp is missing or badly formatted
The authentication token is missing or badly formatted
The payload is missing or badly formatted
The authentication token can’t be verified
Too many requests were sent to the server
An error occurred on the server
